awd_titl_txt: NRT-IGE: STEM Professional Awareness, Advancement, and Development (PAAD)
awd_abstract_narration:
While STEM graduate students have exciting career options that expand upon the technical knowledge gained during their studies, new challenges and opportunities provided by technology advancements, digital influences, and commercialization interests, for example, mandate a revitalization of graduate education.  Because millennial generation students will likely change careers multiple times, students must become trained for a broad variety of employment opportunities. Graduate training, therefore, should incorporate new and transferable skillsets to adequately prepare students for these numerous career paths. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track to the University of Arkansas will develop, test, and assess a curriculum model that incorporates STEM and non-STEM disciplines in professional awareness and development training of STEM graduate students. Additionally, the project will provide an innovative training approach for STEM and non-STEM faculty to think beyond the bounds of traditional academia and to better prepare STEM graduate students for a variety of careers. The project will create a new graduate education training cycle, from recruitment of students to successful graduation and employment, through the incorporation of curricular and co-curricular activities and with significant input from stakeholders in education, government, industry, non-profits, and communities. This new training model will result in better career preparation and success of STEM graduate students through assimilation of new skillsets that include not only depth of expertise in specific technical disciplines, but also a breadth of talent and ability in diverse technical and non-technical areas, such as communication, project planning, and management.   	
				
Based on student, corporate, and community responses to current and previous programs at the University of Arkansas, this project will develop a new model to provide a holistic approach to career awareness, advancement, and development for STEM graduate students by providing broad professional preparation intertwined with technical training. NRT-supported faculty from STEM and non-STEM fields will receive training that will help them propose and develop novel curricular and co-curricular concepts and methods that support one or more of the tracks for student training (patent law, public policy/government, academia, or commercialization/entrepreneurship). Students will select one of these four professional tracks and integrate learning activities that include outreach and experiential learning into their technical programs.  Data collected throughout the project will examine career awareness and placement outcomes, success of the model, and adaptation to other programs.   
       						
The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

por.por_cntn:
The NRT-IGE: STEM Professional Awareness, Advancement, and Development (PAAD) pilot program was developed at the University of Arkansas (UA) to investigate the impact of supplemental training approaches beyond technical STEM graduate education and to prepare students for traditional and non-traditional careers in academia, industry, entrepreneurship, law, government, public policy, and non-profit sectors. The PAAD project allowed STEM graduate students to learn about multiple career options and receive applicable interdisciplinary training for more than one career path, provided training for faculty and staff to think beyond academia and better prepare students for a variety of careers, and involved both STEM and non-STEM disciplines in the professional development training of STEM graduate students.

 

Intellectual Merit

Key components of the PAAD program were identification and creation of educational and professional resources that assist STEM graduate students in learning STEM skills outside selected degree programs and developing non-STEM skills that help advance students' preparation for a variety of careers. Three cohorts of UA STEM graduate students (fifty total) representing twenty-five departments and programs were selected to participate in the project. Ten UA STEM and non-STEM faculty and staff representing ten departments and programs were selected as PAAD faculty fellows to train and help STEM graduate students explore interdisciplinary skill sets and diverse careers. PAAD faculty fellows participated in UA teaching workshops and national conferences that were relevant to the development of eight new PAAD courses and activities. PAAD students selected one or more career areas to explore and completed courses relevant to developing skills outside their degree programs, including courses and activities developed by PAAD faculty fellows and by PAAD leadership. PAAD students reported receiving skills development that they would not have obtained within their primary programs of study, indicating that PAAD courses helped them think more broadly about their primary degree work and expanded their research skills. PAAD students utilized Individual Development Plans (IDPs) and participated in career fairs, outreach activities, and active learning, networking, and mentorship opportunities. The PAAD program was a pilot that assessed the need and interest for developing a UA graduate certificate to prepare STEM and non-STEM students for a variety of careers, particularly those in nonacademic sectors.        

 

Broader Impacts

The PAAD pilot indicated how a program that promotes flexibility by partnering training options of technical STEM skill sets with non-technical, non-STEM skill sets impacts students' skills development and preparedness for a broad range of careers. PAAD students expressed that important benefits of the program were learning new skills not taught in their degree programs and being exposed to career options and innovative partnerships that helped them identify new career opportunities. They also indicated that receiving training in areas outside their degree programs and exploring career options helped them learn why they might not want to pursue specific careers they were previously considering and that this experience was equally valuable. To date, half of the PAAD students have graduated with the degrees they started when joining the program. While some have elected to pursue Ph.D. and postdoctoral positions as next steps, others have pursued positions in nonprofit, government, industry, and startup sectors, as well as faculty and staff positions in academic sectors, in Arkansas and throughout the nation and world. There are direct connections between the education and training provided by PAAD for some of these students and these positions. PAAD students also expressed the significant impact of networking opportunities afforded by the program for both career growth and research collaboration, as well as the impact from exploring outreach and active learning opportunities that offered social, policy, legal, and political training as part of their professional and career development.

PAAD faculty fellows and other UA faculty have recognized the value of PAAD goals, trainings, and impacts and have incorporated PAAD elements into their courses and research, presenting increased opportunities for STEM students to receive skills training, professional development, and mentorship that supplement the research and education in their STEM disciplines. Hundreds of UA STEM and non-STEM faculty and students (graduate and undergraduate) have received educational, networking, and mentorship benefits from PAAD courses, electives, activities, workshops, and trainings. The unique aspect of including non-STEM faculty and staff and skills training in the PAAD program has integrated the training of non-STEM students with STEM students, thus broadening exposure and training in STEM fields, interdisciplinary collaboration, and awareness of career opportunities and leading to a more diverse pipeline of professionals. Additionally, PAAD leadership and faculty fellows disseminated the PAAD model and trainings to statewide and national audiences of students and faculty from other colleges and universities, industry partners, and members of communities and professional organizations. PAAD leadership is partnering with the UA academic colleges, career services, and graduate school to develop a UA graduate certificate that builds on results of the PAAD pilot program, demonstrating commitment to sustaining the PAAD training approach.
